Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Syntax and Semantics of Applicative Morphology in Bantu

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language serves not just as a means of communication but also a window into how humans perceive and categorize the world. Words define basic categories of objects or situations, and contrasts between words with similar but subtly distinct meanings provide clues as to what properties of the world humans find significant. One of the most tantalizing results of the last several decades of linguistic work on word meaning is that a word's meaning also figures into its grammatical properties and can constrain the grammatical contexts in which it occurs, albeit in regular and systematic ways, offering still further clues as to how humans perceive the world. However, the relationship of word meaning to grammar varies among languages. Thus it is important to have a diverse sampling of languages in order to capture the full spectrum of how languages describe the world. This dissertation investigates the grammatical and semantic relationships between word meaning and grammar in the Bantu languages of Sub-Saharan Africa. More broadly, this study incorporates a new set of languages into work on the semantic underpinnings of grammar, an area that to date has focused heavily on European languages. It also promotes academic research on the languages and cultures of Africa, which is important for improving international collaboration. There are many misunderstandings about Africa in American society, especially relating to the geographic, cultural, and linguistic diversity of the people who inhabit the African continent. The inclusion of African languages in linguistic research promotes more dialogue between Western and African voices.

The specific research question concerns the semantics of Bantu "applicative" morphology, a type of optional suffix on a verb that, when present, typically introduces a new participant into the event described by the verb, expressed as a new direct object. While previous approaches to this phenomenon generally predict that the applicative morphology should behave uniformly across all verbs, this study demonstrates that there is a significant interaction of verb and applicative meaning in determining what the semantic function of the applicatives is and the grammatical effects it has.This in turn gives us new insights into how verb meaning constrains the overall grammatical structure and interpretation of the sentence and thus ultimately to how languages construe situations in the world. This dissertation investigates applicative morphology in three Bantu of Eastern Africa: Kinyarwanda (Rwanda), Chichewa (Malawi), and Lubukusu (Kenya). It uses standard elicitation techniques to collect data from native speakers from these different linguistic groups, creating a rich new database of original data, to be analyzed using state-of-the art techniques for analyzing syntax and semantics and the relationship of the two. The outputs are thus a rich new dataset for further research, and also new insights into the universality of human languages and human cognition regarding how speakers construe events in the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Kyle Jerro’s dissertation explores the linguistic meaning contributed by a particular type of verbal suffix called an “applicative.” This suffix, found in various Bantu languages (a family of roughly 450 languages spoken in Sub-Saharan Africa), generally adds a new object (an applied object) to the sentence that refers to an additional participant in the event described by the verb that is not part of the meaning of the verb by itself. The aim of this dissertation was to show that there is more to what applicatives do than just this, and offer a formally precise, explanatory analysis of the various functions of applicatives. Applicatives are interesting because they give us insight into how speakers of languages perceive and construe events they wish to describe. The fundamental function of a verb is to describe events (i.e. happenings in the world) around us, and applicatives are an explicit means for modifying a verb’s meaning in well-defined ways to augment or expand the kind of event being described. By better understanding what applicatives do we have better insights into what properties of events are important within human languages and how more complex events can be constructed and construed.

 

The dissertation pursues three case studies in this domain. First, a study of the applicative suffix -ir in Kinyarwanda shows that an applicative can also create an object referring to a participant that is implicit in the meaning of the verb but is otherwise left unexpressed, and in some cases even alter the interpretation of a participant already expressed as the direct object of the verb. In the first case, when -ir applies to verbs describing motion through space, the applied object refers to a part of the path of motion that is already implicitly a part of the meaning of the verb, where the part of the path (e.g. source, goal, route) is determined on a verb-by-verb basis. In the second case, with certain verbs of throwing -ir changes the interpretation of an object that normally refers to the target of the throwing to make it an entity that receives the thing thrown, turning targeted throwing into attempted giving. The second case study examines Kinyarwanda applicative –ish, which either introduces a new entity that causes the event to occur or else an instrument by which the event is brought about, though not every verb allows both readings. Jerro argues that -ish has a single basic meaning of adding a new cause-effect event into whatever sequence of cause-effect events are already part of the meaning of the verb. This meaning interacts with the basic meanings of different verbs to rule in or out the two possible readings. In both of these two case studies a formal analysis of the relevant verb and applicative meaning is provided in a mathematically-precise theory of the syntax and semantics of languages that explains the observed patterns. In the third case study, a contrastive study of three Bantu languages (Kinyarwanda, Chichewa, and Lubukusu) compares the grammatical properties of the applied objects introduced by various applicatives and the verb’s inherent direct object in terms of which is object acts like “the” direct object of the applicativized verb. Contra prior studies that have suggested that there are consistent patterns within specific languages or specific applicatives, the results of this study show that there is variation even within uses of a single applicative in a given language, hinging on a range of factors including verb type, objecthood property, type of entity the object refers to, and other things.

 

What these studies indicate more broadly is that verb meanings can be explicitly modified in more ways than just by augmenting them with new information. Rather, more subtle restructuring of the information already contained in a verb is another possibility, and interactions of the meanings of the verbs being modified with the suffixes that modify them can produce significant effects, providing insight into the kinds of events languages make relevant to speakers and how those events are related to one another. Finally, the study also has the broader impact of shifting the focus of work on word meaning into lesser studied languages. The vast majority work on the semantics of verbs over the last several decades has focused on English and other European languages. This study brings both new data from new language types to bear on analyses of word meaning, but also affords greater prominence to languages such as Lubukusu, a minority language of Kenya, and two more established national languages of African countries, Kinyarwanda in Rwanda and Chichewa in Malawi, that have not to date played as significant a role in theorizing about word meaning. Overall, this dissertation will thus help bring attention to the linguistic diversity of Eastern Africa.
